answers.author: Gary Wallis
answers.text:
I just came back from a conference where Albany, Oregon presented their Dashboard, an online window into the city's financial, performance measures and other related information. They have set the transparency bar very high. The site has been operational for about 6 months and has been written up in several publications. Surprising to me is that the local citizens have not raised questions and the site is not getting many hits. Besides the Dashboard they have very interesting information on revenues on a related link "Where Does My Money Go?" Try this link to get to both the Dashboard and Money: http://www.cityofalbany.net/finance/revenues/
My organization will be looking into whether we want to offer something similar.

answers.author: Timothy McLean
answers.text:
Shelley, Have you considered creating a "dashboard" for the city website? Based on a similar model from the State of Michigan, we (City of Troy) are in the process of creating our own dashboard. We are using such indicators as the cost of government, economic strength, quality of life, and public safety. We liked the idea of creating a dashboard because it gives citizens an idea of where we are at without forcing them to read through all types of data. We are still in the production stages and hope to pilot test our dashboard indicators on a focus group in the next few weeks.

answers.author: Robert Woods
answers.text:
Go to www.sunshinereview.org which is an independent organization (not govt workers) who have established transparency criteria. Take a look, it was not hard for us to get an A+ rating.
We (the City of Albany) were just cited by the American Society of News Editors as part of Local Heroes Award program for national Sunshine Week (Which ends Sunday Mar 20) for our web site.

author: Shelley Hearn
text:
I am looking for communities that have created open/transparency webpages. What type of information is included and how has the city checkbook been incorporated? Was special software or programming developed to consolidate payments to individuals for assistance to protect their privacy or to display the information in a user friendly format? 
What other information have cities included in addition to financial data? Has there been any reaction from the public or media from the website?
Were there any legal challenges regarding privacy and release of information that need to be addressed?
title: Government Transparency Websites
